item.name: Barding
item.text: Barding is armor designed to protect an animal’s head, neck, chest, and body. Any type of armor can be purchased as barding. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much. Applicable Armor: Name Type AC Strength Stealth Padded Light  11 + Dex modifier  -- Disadvantage Leather Light  11 + Dex modifier  --  -- Studded Leather Light  12 + Dex modifier  --  -- Hide Medium  12 + Dex modifier  --  -- (max 2) Chain Shirt Medium  13 + Dex modifier  --  -- (max 2) Scale Mail Medium  14 + Dex modifier  --  Disadvantage (max 2) Breastplate Medium  14 + Dex modifier  --  -- (max 2) Half Plate Medium  15 + Dex modifier  -- Disadvantage (max 2) Ring Mail Heavy  14  --  Disadvantage Chain Mail Heavy  16  Strength 13  Disadvantage Splint Heavy  17  Strength 15  Disadvantage Plate Heavy  18  Strength 15  Disadvantage Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Bit and Bridle
item.text: Standard equipment used to direct a mount. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Feed (per day)
item.text: Standard feed typically consumed by a mount per day. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Saddlebags
item.text: Standard saddlebags that can be attached to a mount's saddle. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Carriage
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Cart
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Chariot
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Sled
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Wagon
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Galley
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Keelboat
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. One of the smallest sailing vessels, [vehicle]keelboat;keelboats[/vehicle] can be sailed or rowed by a single person. These ships often transport small amounts of cargo or passengers. They're perfect for pleasure cruises, as they're easier and less expensive to operate than larger vessels. Keelboats and rowboats are used on lakes and rivers. If going downstream, add the speed of the current (typically 3 miles per hour) to the speed of the vehicle. These vehicles can’t be rowed against any significant current, but they can be pulled upstream by draft animals on the shores. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Longship
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Rowboat
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. [vehicle]Rowboat;Rowboats[/vehicle] are used on lakes and rivers. If going downstream, add the speed of the current (typically 3 miles per hour) to the speed of the vehicle. These vehicles can’t be rowed against any significant current, but they can be pulled upstream by draft animals on the shores. A rowboat weighs 100 pounds, in case adventurers carry it over land. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Sailing Ship
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Warship
item.text: If you have proficiency with a certain kind of vehicle (land or water), you can add your proficiency bonus to any check you make to control that kind of vehicle in difficult circumstances. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Saddle, Exotic
item.text: An exotic saddle is required for riding any aquatic or flying mount. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Saddle, Military
item.text: A military saddle braces the rider, helping you keep your seat on an active mount in battle. It gives you advantage on any check you make to remain mounted. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Saddle, Pack
item.text: A standard saddle for a pack mount. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Saddle, Riding
item.text: A standard saddle for a riding mount. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Three-Dragon Ante Set
item.text: If you are proficient with a gaming set, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks you make to play a game with that set. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Dragonchess Set
item.text: If you are proficient with a gaming set, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks you make to play a game with that set. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Monster Hunter's Pack
item.text: Includes a chest, a crowbar, a hammer, three wooden stakes, a holy symbol, a flask of holy water, a set of manacles, a steel mirror, a flask of oil, a tinderbox, and 3 torches. Source: Curse of Strahd: Character Options

item.name: Bullets, Renaissance
item.text: The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use. Renaissance and modern firearms use bullets. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Bullets, Modern
item.text: The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use. Renaissance and modern firearms use bullets. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Energy Cell
item.text: The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use. Futuristic firearms are powered by a special type of ammunition called energy cells. An energy cell contains enough power for all the shots its firearm can make. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Bomb
item.text: As an action, a character can light this bomb and throw it at a point up to 60 feet away. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 3d6 [rule]fire damage[/rule]. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Gunpowder, Keg
item.text: Gunpowder is chiefly used to propel a bullet out of the barrel of a pistol or rifle, or it is formed into a bomb. Gunpowder is sold in small wooden kegs and in water-resistant powder horns. Setting fire to a container full of gunpowder can cause it to explode, dealing fire damage to creatures within 10 feet of it (3d6 for a powder horn, 7d6 for a keg). A successful DC 12 Dexterity saving throw halves the damage. Setting fire to an ounce of gunpowder causes it to flare for 1 round, shedding bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Gunpowder, Powder Horn
item.text: Gunpowder is chiefly used to propel a bullet out of the barrel of a pistol or rifle, or it is formed into a bomb. Gunpowder is sold in small wooden kegs and in water-resistant powder horns. Setting fire to a container full of gunpowder can cause it to explode, dealing fire damage to creatures within 10 feet of it (3d6 for a powder horn, 7d6 for a keg). A successful DC 12 Dexterity saving throw halves the damage. Setting fire to an ounce of gunpowder causes it to flare for 1 round, shedding bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Dynamite (Stick)
item.text: As an action, a creature can light a stick of dynamite and throw it at a point up to 60 feet away. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 3d6 bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A character can bind sticks of dynamite together so they explode at the same time. Each additional stick increases the damage by 1d6 (to a maximum of 10d6) and the burst radius by 5 feet (to a maximum of 20 feet). Dynamite can be rigged with a longer fuse to explode after a set amount of time, usually 1 to 6 rounds. Roll initiative for the dynamite. After the set number of rounds goes by, the dynamite explodes on that initiative. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Grenade, Fragmentation
item.text: As an action, a character can throw a grenade at a point up to 60 feet away. With a grenade launcher, the character can propel the grenade up to 120 feet away. Each creature within 20 feet of an exploding fragmentation grenade must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 5d6 piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Grenade, Smoke
item.text: As an action, a character can throw a grenade at a point up to 60 feet away. With a grenade launcher, the character can propel the grenade up to 120 feet away. One round after a smoke grenade lands, it emits a cloud of smoke that creates a heavily obscured area in a 20-foot radius. A moderate wind (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses the smoke in 4 rounds; a strong wind (20 or more miles per hour) disperses it in 1 round. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Grenade Launcher
item.text: As an action, a character can throw a grenade at a point up to 60 feet away. With a grenade launcher, the character can propel the grenade up to 120 feet away. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Antitoxin
item.text: A creature that drinks this vial of liquid gains advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour. It confers no benefit to undead or constructs. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: String
item.text: A 10-foot length of string, typically found in a burglar's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Stake (Wooden)
item.text: Stakes made out of wood, typically found in a monster hunter's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Alms Box
item.text: A small box for alms, typically found in a priest's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Block of Incense
item.text: A block of incense, typically found in a priest's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Censer
item.text: A censer, typically found in a priest's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Vestments
item.text: Religious clothing, typically found in a priest's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Little Bag of Sand
item.text: A small bag of sand, typically found in a scholar's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Small Knife
item.text: A small knife, typically found in a scholar's pack. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Holy Symbol
item.text: A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon. A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, as described in the Spellcasting section. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Druidic Focus
item.text: A druid can use a Sprig of Mistletoe (or holly) as a spellcasting focus, as described in the Spellcasting section. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Arcane Focus
item.text: An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus, as described in the Spellcasting section. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Palm Pistol Bullets
item.text: Firearm bullets are used with a weapon that has the reload property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). Source: Critical Role

item.name: Pistol (Exandria) Bullets
item.text: Firearm bullets are used with a weapon that has the reload property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). Source: Critical Role

Drawing the ammunition from a case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). Source: Critical Role

item.name: Bad News Bullets
item.text: Firearm bullets are used with a weapon that has the reload property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). Source: Critical Role

item.name: Hand Mortar Ammunition
item.text: Hand mortar ammunition is used with a hand mortar to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). Source: Critical Role

item.name: Birdpipes
item.text: Pan pipes or satyr pipes, also known as the shalm, these are sacred to Lliira and popular with wood elf and wild elf bards. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Glaur
item.text: Short, curved horns like a cornucopia. Played with valves, glaur sound like trumpets, while those without valves, known as gloon, have a more mournful sound. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Hand Drum
item.text: A double-headed skin drum fitted with handles along its side. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Longhorn
item.text: A Faerûnian flute of sophisticated make, found only in areas with skilled artisans, as in great cities or elven enclaves. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Songhorn
item.text: A recorder, a simple type of flute, usually carved from wood. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Tantan
item.text: A tambourine, a popular instrument with halflings and humans south of the Dalelands. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Thelarr
item.text: Also known as a whistlecane, a simple and easy-to-make wind instrument cut from a reed. They are so simple, in fact, that skilled bards frequently make and give them away to children - to the parents’ delight or regret. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Tocken
item.text: A hanging set of carved oval bells, usually played with a pair of light wooden hammers (or open handed). They are most common in underground cultures, where the resonant tones can carry. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Wargong
item.text: A metal gong, traditionally made from a shield, particularly the shield of an enemy. Both goblins and dwarves make and play wargongs, their sound echoing through tunnels in the Underdark. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Yarting
item.text: A southern instrument from Amn and Calimshan that is a Faerûnian analog to the guitar. Numerous variations have spread across the continent. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Zulkoon
item.text: A complex pump organ that originated with the zulkirs of Thay, who use it in the casting of their spells. It is considered to have a dramatic, but sinister, sound. Source: Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide

item.name: Azurite
item.text: An opaque mottled deep blue gemstone worth 10 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Bloodstone
item.text: An opaque dark gray gemstone with red flecks worth 50 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Moonstone
item.text: A translucent white gemstone with a pale blue glow worth 50 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Zircon
item.text: A transparent pale blue-green gemstone worth 50 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Amber
item.text: A transparent watery gold to rich gold gemstone worth 100 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Jacinth
item.text: A transparent fiery orange gem worth 5,000 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Aquamarine
item.text: A transparent pale blue-green gemstone worth 500 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Blue Sapphire
item.text: A transparent blue-white to medium blue gemstone worth 1,000 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Star Ruby
item.text: A translucent ruby gemstone with a white star-shaped center worth 1,000 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Ruby
item.text: A transparent clear red to deep crimson gemstone worth 5,000 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Star Sapphire
item.text: A translucent blue sapphire gemstone with a white star-shaped center worth 1,000 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Black Opal
item.text: A translucent dark green with black mottling and golden flecks gemstone worth 1,000 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Diamond
item.text: A transparent blue-white, canary, pink, brown, or blue gemstone worth 5,000 gold pieces.  Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Blue spinel
item.text: A transparent deep blue gemstone worth 500 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Garnet
item.text: A transparent red, brown-green, or violet gemstone worth 100 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Opal
item.text: A translucent pale blue with green and golden mottling gemstone worth 1,000 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Yellow sapphire
item.text: A transparent fiery yellow or yellow-green gemstone worth 1,000 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Topaz
item.text: A transparent golden yellow gemstone worth 500 gold pieces Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Hematite
item.text: An opaque gray-black gemstone worth 10 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Lapis Lazuli
item.text: An opaque light and dark blue gemstone with yellow flecks worth 10 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Chalcedony
item.text: An opaque white gemstone worth 50 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Star Rose Quartz
item.text: A translucent rosy Gemstone with a white star-shaped center worth 50 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Amethyst
item.text: A transparent deep purple gemstone worth 100 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Jet
item.text: An opaque deep black gemstone worth 100 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Pearl
item.text: An opaque lustrous white, yellow, or pink gemstone worth 100 gold pieces. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Black Pearl

item.name: Net
item.text: Proficiency with a net allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it. A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is restrained until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net. When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Boomerang
item.text: The boomerang is a ranged weapon, and any creature proficient with the javelin is also proficient with this weapon. On a miss, a boomerang returns to the thrower's hand. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Yklwa
item.text: A yklwa (pronounced YICK-ul-wah) is a simple melee weapon that is the traditional weapon of Chultan warriors. A yklwa consists of a 3-foot wooden shaft with a steel or stone blade up to 18 inches long. It costs 1 gp, and it deals 1d8 piercing damage on a hit. Although it has the thrown weapon property, the yklwa is not well balanced for throwing (range 10/30 ft.). Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Pistol
item.text: It’s up to you to decide whether a character has proficiency with a firearm. Characters in most D&D worlds wouldn’t have such proficiency. During their downtime, characters can use the training rules in the Player’s Handbook to acquire proficiency, assuming that they have enough ammunition to keep the weapons working while mastering their use. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Palm Pistol (Exandria)
item.text: Firearms are a new and volatile technology, and as such bring their own unique set of weapon properties. Some properties are followed by a number, and this number signifies an element of that property (outlined below). These properties replace the optional ones presented in the Dungeon Master’s Guide. Firearms are ranged weapons. Reload. The weapon can be fired a number of times equal to its Reload score before you must spend 1 attack or 1 action to reload. You must have one free hand to reload a firearm. Misfire. Whenever you make an attack roll with a firearm, and the dice roll is equal to or lower than the weapon’s Misfire score, the weapon misfires. The attack misses, and the weapon cannot be used again until you spend an action to try and repair it. To repair your firearm, you must make a successful Tinker’s Tools check (DC equal to 8 + misfire score). If your check fails, the weapon is broken and must be mended out of combat at a quarter of the cost of the firearm. Creatures who use a firearm without being proficient increase the weapon’s misfire score by 1. Explosive. Upon a hit, everything within 5 ft of the target must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Dexterity modifier) or suffer 1d8 fire damage. If the weapon misses, the ammunition fails to detonate, or bounces away harmlessly before doing so. Ammunition All firearms require ammunition to make an attack, and due to their rare nature, ammunition may be near impossible to find or purchase. However, if materials are gathered, you can craft ammunition yourself using your Tinker’s Tools at half the cost. Each firearm uses its own unique ammunition and is generally sold or crafted in batches listed below next to the price. ---------------------------------------- THIS IS UNOFFICIAL MATERIAL These game mechanics are usable in your campaign if your DM allows them but not refined by final game design and editing. They aren’t officially part of the Dungeons & Dragons game and aren’t permitted in D&D Adventurers League events unless otherwise stated. ---------------------------------------- Source: Critical Role

item.name: Double-Bladed Scimitar
item.text: The double-bladed scimitar is the signature weapon of Valenar elves. A haft of fine wood supports a long, curving blade on either end. Forged with techniques honed over centuries, these blades are strong, sharp, and remarkably light. Each scimitar is a masterpiece, and as a result the double-bladed scimitar is an expensive weapon (100 gp) - few though ever have the opportunity to purchase one. A Valenar blade in the hands of a non-elf is generally assumed to have been stolen or looted from a fallen foe, and a Valenar elf might feel entitled to demand its return or challenge the bearer to prove they’re worthy to wield it. Special. If you attack with a double-bladed scimitar as part of the Attack action on your turn, you can use a bonus action immediately after to make a melee attack with it. This attack deals 1d4 slashing damage on a hit, instead of 2d4. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Studded Leather
item.text: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Scale Mail
item.text: This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Shield
item.text: A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Padded
item.text: Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Leather
item.text: The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Hide
item.text: This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Chain Shirt
item.text: Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Breastplate
item.text: This armor consists of a fitted metal chest piece worn with supple leather. Although it leaves the legs and arms relatively unprotected, this armor provides good protection for the wearer's vital organs while leaving the wearer relatively unencumbered. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Half Plate
item.text: Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearer's body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Ring Mail
item.text: This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and it's usually worn only by those who can't afford better armor. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Chain Mail
item.text: Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows. The suit includes gauntlets. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Splint
item.text: This armor is made of narrow vertical strips of metal riveted to a backing of leather that is worn over cloth padding. Flexible chain mail protects the joints. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Plate
item.text: Plate consists of shaped, interlocking metal plates to cover the entire body. A suit of plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook

item.name: Spiked Armor
item.text: Spiked armor is a rare type of medium armor made by dwarves. It consists of a leather coat and leggings covered with spikes that are usually made of metal. Source: Basic Rules, Player’s Handbook
